column4: I had a problem with my network when using ubuntu. someone told me I needed to make ubuntu act as a DHCP Client in order for it all to work. Looking in the packages section there are 3 different ones. dhcp-client (2.0pl5-19.5ubuntu2) /// dhcp3-client (3.0.4-12ubuntu1) /// dhcpcd (1:2.0.3-1). Which one should I use?
there should be dhcp3-client installed by default for desktop installations
the command you need to run is "sudo dhclient eth0" if your network adapter is eth0.
run 'ifconfig'  Dhcp should be automatically used unless you changed the configuration
we still need to see the output of 'ifconfig' from a command line.  Application --> Accessories --> Terminal
it sounds like ubuntu is running as a dhcp server.
you can verify by running 'dpkg -l dhcp*' and see if dhcpd has ii as the first two characters (it stands for commanded to install and installed successfully)
you will want to uninstall the dhcp server with 'sudo apt-get uninstall dhcpd'
did you uninstall the dhcpd application?
right now you have  ubuntu and your router acting as competing dhcp servers.  You can temporarily disable dhcpd with a 'sudo /etc/init.d/dhcpd stop'
eventually you will need to uninstall it from ubuntu.  if you run the last command, you will stop it until the next time ubuntu restarts
the command to uninstall dhcpd is 'sudo apt-get uninstall dhcpd'
you will also have to make sure that your /etc/network/interfaces file has a dhcp address defined instead of a static address
run 'sudo gedit /etc/network/interfaces' and verify that you have a 'iface eth0 inet dhcp'
